articles.headline: In Sweden, an Experiment Turns Shorter Workdays Into Bigger Gains
articles.snippet: A trial in the city of Gothenburg mandates a six-hour day and is testing whether it can reduce absenteeism and increase productivity.
articles.abstract: A trial in the city of Gothenburg mandates a six-hour day and is testing whether it can reduce absenteeism and increase productivity.
articles.lead_paragraph: GOTHENBURG, Sweden — Arturo Perez used to come home frazzled from his job as a caregiver at the Svartedalens nursing home. Eight-hour stretches of tending to residents with senility or Alzheimer’s would leave him sapped with little time to spend with his three children.

articles.headline: Giving Like Michael Bloomberg: ‘Find One Small Thing’
articles.snippet: Observing how philanthropists like the former New York mayor collaborate with others can help smaller donors make a bigger difference.
articles.abstract: Observing how philanthropists like the former New York mayor collaborate with others can help smaller donors make a bigger difference.
articles.lead_paragraph: The two imposing brownstones on the Upper East Side of Manhattan that are home to Bloomberg Philanthropies give off the aura of a modern-day Medici palace, a fitting setting for Michael R. Bloomberg, media mogul, former mayor of New York and one of the top philanthropists in America.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Tells N.R.A. Hillary Clinton Wants to Let Violent Criminals Go Free
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump, accepting the endorsement of the National Rifle Association, said Mrs. Clinton’s desire for stricter gun controls would put law-abiding citizens at risk.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump, accepting the endorsement of the National Rifle Association, said Mrs. Clinton’s desire for stricter gun controls would put law-abiding citizens at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Donald J. Trump accused Hillary Clinton on Friday of wanting to let violent criminals out of prison and “disarm” law-abiding citizens in unsafe neighborhoods, and warned that women, in particular, would be at greater risk if she were elected president.

articles.headline: As Hamas Tunnels Back Into Israel, Palestinians Are Afraid, Too
articles.snippet: Hamas is busy tunneling its way back toward Israel, and Palestinians who live over the passageways fear they will bear the cost of the eventual Israeli response.
articles.abstract: Hamas is busy tunneling its way back toward Israel, and Palestinians who live over the passageways fear they will bear the cost of the eventual Israeli response.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHUZAA, Gaza Strip — The attack tunnels Hamas has constructed running from Gaza into Israel have long sown deep fears in the communities on the Israeli side of the border fence, where residents talk of nightmares about Palestinian militants popping up into their dining rooms or kindergartens.
articles.byline: By Diaa Hadid and Majd Al Waheidi

articles.headline: Political Rifts Over Bill Clinton’s Welfare Law Resurface as Aid Shrinks
articles.snippet: Some states are limiting cash benefits for families, rekindling concerns — some on the Democratic campaign trail — about a law signed 20 years ago.
articles.abstract: Some states are limiting cash benefits for families, rekindling concerns — some on the Democratic campaign trail — about a law signed 20 years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — With little debate, Arizona last year became the only state to impose a one-year limit on cash assistance to needy families, cutting the maximum duration of benefits for the third time since 2010. The newest limit has begun to hit home for welfare recipients who are learning that their benefits are nearing an end.

articles.headline: Facebook ‘Trending’ List Skewed by Individual Judgment, Not Institutional Bias
articles.snippet: Facebook employees weren’t directed to squelch conservative news on the site’s Trending Topics, nor would that be easily accomplished by a staff member who wished to do so.
articles.abstract: Facebook employees weren’t directed to squelch conservative news on the site’s Trending Topics, nor would that be easily accomplished by a staff member who wished to do so.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last July, in a seventh-floor conference room at Facebook’s Lower Manhattan offices, a small group met to discuss the future of news media on the social network.

articles.headline: Start-Ups Once Showered With Cash Now Have to Work for It
articles.snippet: Instead of venture capitalists begging to invest in start-ups, entrepreneurs are begging for cash, and potential investors are making demands.
articles.abstract: Instead of venture capitalists begging to invest in start-ups, entrepreneurs are begging for cash, and potential investors are making demands.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Jeremy Hitchcock raised money for his technology start-up in 2012, he barely had to break a sweat. He was flooded with emails from venture capitalists who wanted in. Two months after meeting an investor over cocktails at a technology conference, he scored $38 million.

articles.headline: Viacom Fight Escalates as Redstone Moves Against Company Chief
articles.snippet: Sumner Redstone ousted Viacom’s chief executive and a Viacom director from the trust that will eventually control Mr. Redstone’s stake.
articles.abstract: Sumner Redstone ousted Viacom’s chief executive and a Viacom director from the trust that will eventually control Mr. Redstone’s stake.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fight for control over Sumner M. Redstone’s $40 billion media empire has escalated significantly.

articles.headline: Economic Promises a President Trump Could (and Couldn’t) Keep
articles.snippet: Much of what Donald Trump vows to accomplish in his first 100 days, if elected, is not feasible. But that doesn’t mean he wouldn’t have room to maneuver.
articles.abstract: Much of what Donald Trump vows to accomplish in his first 100 days, if elected, is not feasible. But that doesn’t mean he wouldn’t have room to maneuver.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the hills and hollows of Mingo County, W.Va., where unemployment is nearly triple the national average, it’s coal. On the southwest side of Chicago, where the landscape couldn’t be more different but the economic fears are much the same, it’s Oreo cookies. Elsewhere, it is cars, computers and air-conditioners.

articles.headline: Key G.O.P. Donors Still Deeply Resist Donald Trump’s Candidacy
articles.snippet: A survey of more than 50 of the most generous donors to Republican candidates and advocacy groups revealed contempt and distrust toward their own party’s nominee.
articles.abstract: A survey of more than 50 of the most generous donors to Republican candidates and advocacy groups revealed contempt and distrust toward their own party’s nominee.
articles.lead_paragraph: A powerful array of the Republican Party’s largest financial backers remains deeply resistant to Donald J. Trump’s presidential candidacy, forming a wall of opposition that could make it exceedingly difficult for him to meet his goal of raising $1 billion before the November election.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: How Kosovo Was Turned Into Fertile Ground for ISIS
articles.snippet: Extremist clerics and secretive associations funded by Saudis and others have transformed a once-tolerant Muslim society into a font of extremism.
articles.abstract: Extremist clerics and secretive associations funded by Saudis and others have transformed a once-tolerant Muslim society into a font of extremism.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRISTINA, Kosovo — Every Friday, just yards from a statue of Bill Clinton with arm aloft in a cheery wave, hundreds of young bearded men make a show of kneeling to pray on the sidewalk outside an improvised mosque in a former furniture store.

articles.headline: How the Push to Advance Bathroom Rights for Transgender Americans Reached the White House
articles.snippet: As the issue of bathroom access grew, the Obama administration was heavily lobbied by rights groups, and resistance escalated in state legislatures and school districts.
articles.abstract: As the issue of bathroom access grew, the Obama administration was heavily lobbied by rights groups, and resistance escalated in state legislatures and school districts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The people of Palatine, Ill., a middle-class suburb of Chicago marked by generic strip malls and tidy cul-de-sacs, had not spent much time debating the thorny questions of transgender rights. But in late 2013, a transgender high school athlete, so intent on defending her privacy that she is known only as Student A, took on her school district so she could use the girls’ locker room.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Julie Bosman, Manny Fernandez and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: A Venture Fund With Plenty of Virtual Capital, but No Capitalist
articles.snippet: This collective digital-currency start-up runs head-on into regulatory obstacles, yet might very well upend the mysterious world of virtual investing.
articles.abstract: This collective digital-currency start-up runs head-on into regulatory obstacles, yet might very well upend the mysterious world of virtual investing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Olivier Stern, a 31-year-old French socialist with an appetite for risk, recently invested a third of his life savings — 10,000 euros, about $11,000 — in a cryptocurrency start-up that has no legal standing and runs head-on into regulatory obstacles, yet might very well upend the mysterious world of virtual investing.

articles.headline: Unemployed Detroit Residents Are Trapped by a Digital Divide
articles.snippet: About 40 percent of Detroit’s residents lack broadband access, even on their phones, which makes finding and applying for jobs increasingly difficult.
articles.abstract: About 40 percent of Detroit’s residents lack broadband access, even on their phones, which makes finding and applying for jobs increasingly difficult.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In downtown Detroit, start-ups and luxury retailers are opening up and new office buildings are being built as the city works to recover from its deep economic problems.

articles.headline: Taliban Chief Targeted by Drone Strike in Pakistan, Signaling a U.S. Shift
articles.snippet: The strike, which Afghan intelligence said had killed the leader, indicated a major break with precedent as the United States circumvented Pakistan, which has been unable to broker peace talks with the Taliban.
articles.abstract: The strike, which Afghan intelligence said had killed the leader, indicated a major break with precedent as the United States circumvented Pakistan, which has been unable to broker peace talks with the Taliban.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — After months of failed Pakistani efforts to broker peace talks with the Taliban, an American drone strike against the leader of the Afghan militants signaled a major break with precedent as the United States circumvented Pakistan in an effort to disrupt the strengthening insurgency, officials said on Sunday.

articles.headline: Entrusted to Save Brazil: The Party That Ruined Rio
articles.snippet: The country’s new governing party has long wielded great power in this oil-rich state — a place afflicted by crime, graft, pollution and economic woes.
articles.abstract: The country’s new governing party has long wielded great power in this oil-rich state — a place afflicted by crime, graft, pollution and economic woes.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Students are taking over Rio de Janeiro schools to protest crippling education cuts, while the politician who helped bring the Summer Olympics to this city is battling allegations that he pocketed millions in bribes.

articles.headline: A Drumbeat of Multiple Shootings, but America Isn’t Listening
articles.snippet: Most shootings with four deaths or injuries are invisible outside their communities. And most of the lives they scar are black.
articles.abstract: Most shootings with four deaths or injuries are invisible outside their communities. And most of the lives they scar are black.
articles.lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — After the slaughter of nine worshipers at a South Carolina church last June, but before the massacre of eight students and a teacher at an Oregon community college in October, there was a shooting that the police here have labeled Incident 159022597.01. It happened on a clear Friday night at an Elks Lodge, on a modest block of clapboard houses northeast of this city’s hilly downtown. Unlike the butchery that bookended it, it merited no presidential statements, no saturation television coverage.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, Daniela Porat and Agustin Armendariz

articles.headline: Decades After ‘Boom-Boom Room’ Suit, Bias Persists for Women
articles.snippet: Sexual harassment is less blatant, but complaints continue about pay and promotion disparities and limited ability to recover damages.
articles.abstract: Sexual harassment is less blatant, but complaints continue about pay and promotion disparities and limited ability to recover damages.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twenty-six years after a co-worker at Smith Barney sexually assaulted her at work, Lisa Mays says she still trembles when she tells the story.

articles.headline: Facebook’s Troubling One-Way Mirror
articles.snippet: The social network requires a level of trust from its users as it seeks to “make the world more open and connected.” But how open is it willing to be?
articles.abstract: The social network requires a level of trust from its users as it seeks to “make the world more open and connected.” But how open is it willing to be?
articles.lead_paragraph: If you bothered to read the fine print when you created your Facebook account, you would have noticed just how much of yourself you were giving over to Mark Zuckerberg and his $340 billion social network.

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Makes a Campaign Mark. Now, Can He Make a Legacy?
articles.snippet: Far from laying the foundation to transform a presidential bid into a fierce progressive movement, Mr. Sanders is wrapped up in the race itself.
articles.abstract: Far from laying the foundation to transform a presidential bid into a fierce progressive movement, Mr. Sanders is wrapped up in the race itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: Congressional candidates who speak of “liberating the American underclass” are flush with campaign donations. The likely Democratic presidential nominee has not only moved to the left on a range of issues, but now routinely rails against the influence of “big money.”
articles.byline: By Jonathan Mahler and Yamiche Alcindor

articles.headline: Hollywood Rushes to VidCon to Connect With Millennials
articles.snippet: The convention brings together online video creators and their fans. Roughly 30,000 people are expected to attend this year, and previews from 20th Century Fox, Lionsgate and Warner Bros. will be presented.
articles.abstract: The convention brings together online video creators and their fans. Roughly 30,000 people are expected to attend this year, and previews from 20th Century Fox, Lionsgate and Warner Bros. will be presented.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Ask movie marketers about the value of fan conventions, and their answer usually starts with an exhausted sigh. Between Comic-Con and WonderCon and Dragon Con, just to name a few, there are more cons than they need or want.

articles.headline: In Sheldon Adelson’s Newsroom, Looser Purse Strings and a Tighter Leash
articles.snippet: At the Las Vegas paper now owned by the casino magnate, current and former employees cite untenable editorial oversight, particularly of coverage related to Mr. Adelson.
articles.abstract: At the Las Vegas paper now owned by the casino magnate, current and former employees cite untenable editorial oversight, particularly of coverage related to Mr. Adelson.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late January, about a half-dozen reporters from The Las Vegas Review-Journal gathered at a colleague’s apartment after work.

articles.headline: Redstone and Viacom Executives Go to Court Against Each Other
articles.snippet: Philippe P. Dauman, ousted from Sumner M. Redstone’s powerful trust, claimed that Shari Redstone had unduly influenced her father; Mr. Redstone countersued.
articles.abstract: Philippe P. Dauman, ousted from Sumner M. Redstone’s powerful trust, claimed that Shari Redstone had unduly influenced her father; Mr. Redstone countersued.
articles.lead_paragraph: The vicious battle over the future of Sumner M. Redstone’s $40 billion media empire boiled over from the public stage into courtrooms on both coasts Monday.

articles.headline: As Trump and Clinton Clash, 2 Operatives Duke It Out in Their Shadows
articles.snippet: David Brock, a supporter of Hillary Clinton, and Roger J. Stone Jr., a backer of Donald J. Trump, bring a passion for their sides and a zeal for attacking critics of their candidates.
articles.abstract: David Brock, a supporter of Hillary Clinton, and Roger J. Stone Jr., a backer of Donald J. Trump, bring a passion for their sides and a zeal for attacking critics of their candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: One takes a pint-size dog named Toby almost everywhere, smokes electronic cigarettes and wears his silver hair in a sweeping pompadour.

articles.headline: Austrian Far-Right Candidate Norbert Hofer Narrowly Loses Presidential Vote
articles.snippet: Mr. Hofer lost to Alexander Van der Bellen, a 72-year-old economics professor and former Green Party leader.
articles.abstract: Mr. Hofer lost to Alexander Van der Bellen, a 72-year-old economics professor and former Green Party leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Alexander Van der Bellen, a 72-year-old economics professor and former Green Party leader, won Austria’s cliffhanger presidential election on Monday, defeating his far-right rival by the slimmest of margins and pledging to unite the divided country.

articles.headline: Police Officer in Freddie Gray Case Is Acquitted of All Charges
articles.snippet: Officer Edward M. Nero’s trial in Baltimore renewed questions about when police officers can stop a private citizen and what they are allowed to do.
articles.abstract: Officer Edward M. Nero’s trial in Baltimore renewed questions about when police officers can stop a private citizen and what they are allowed to do.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The acquittal Monday of a police officer charged in the arrest of Freddie Gray, the black man who suffered a fatal spinal cord injury while in police custody last year, immediately renewed questions of whether any of the six police officers charged in the case would be convicted in connection with his death.
articles.byline: By Jess Bidgood and Timothy Williams

articles.headline: Tribune Publishing, With New Backer, Rejects Gannett’s Bid
articles.snippet: The newspaper company’s strategy to remain a stand-alone company was backed up by a $70.5 million investment by Nant Capital.
articles.abstract: The newspaper company’s strategy to remain a stand-alone company was backed up by a $70.5 million investment by Nant Capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Tribune Publishing Company is testing Gannett’s limits.

articles.headline: Trump Boasts of Rapport With Wall St., but the Feeling Is Not Quite Mutual
articles.snippet: An examination of financial records shows that Donald J. Trump’s relationship with the financial industry is more nuanced than he suggests.
articles.abstract: An examination of financial records shows that Donald J. Trump’s relationship with the financial industry is more nuanced than he suggests.
articles.lead_paragraph: By Donald Trump’s reckoning, his relationship with Wall Street could not be better.
